headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Welcome to the Avago Technologies Limited First Quarter Fiscal Year 2014 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Bin Jiang, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tony Maslowski, Chief Financial Officer of Avago Technologies. 
After the market closed today, Avago distributed a press release and the financial tables describing our financial performance for the first quarter of fiscal year 2014. If you did not receive a copy, you can obtain the information from the Investors section of Avago's website at avagotech.com. This conference call is being webcast live, and a recording will be available via telephone playback for 1 week. It'll also be archived in the Investors section of our website. 
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Tony will be providing details of our first fiscal quarter results, background to our Q2 2014 outlook and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments. 
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Avago reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results. Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statement made on this call. 
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Hock Tan. Hock?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you, Bin. Good afternoon, everyone. We are going to start today by reviewing recent market business highlights in our end markets, then Tony will provide a summary of the first quarter fiscal 2014 financial results. 
Revenue from our first quarter was $709 million and represented a decrease of 4% from last quarter and an increase of 23% from the same quarter a year ago. Now Q1 revenue came in slightly better than the midpoint of our initial guidance. Sequentially, seasonal down trends provided some headwinds in our wired and industrial business, even if strong demand from a major smartphone OEM sustained our record wireless revenue through this quarter and backed the historical norm of a revenue decline in wireless in Q1. Having said all that, the key message I want to impart this quarter is simply that we have significant year-on-year revenue growth in wireless, that's 13% year-on-year, and wired infrastructure at 59% year-on-year and have seen a clear recovery in industrial end demand from a year ago. 
Let me now provide more color on each of our end markets, starting with wireless. Revenue from wireless came in slightly above our expectation, growing 1% sequentially and represented 49% of our total revenues. On a year-on-year basis, as I mentioned, revenue -- wireless revenue grew 13%. And as mentioned earlier, normally, our fiscal Q1 is a seasonally weak quarter for wireless. However, sustained demand from a large OEM customer during the quarter helped us achieve a second consecutive quarter of record wireless revenue. This period, I would also like to highlight an exciting development, and it should come as no surprise that the push into LTE among carriers in China has enabled us to now design in meaningful content in the mass-market China smartphones for the first time. This trend was significant enough to substantially grow our mix of FBAR revenue and expand wireless gross margin during the quarter. 
Looking towards Q2 of fiscal 2014, similar to last year, the annual product transition at this same large OEM I referred to earlier will now be a significant headwind. However, we expect this may be partially offset by initial product ramp and another large OEM customer where we have won significant RF content. Moreover, we see in this quarter the proliferation by multiple white box OEMs of LTE-enabled handsets in China, which would accelerate demand for FBAR filters. The expected surge of our FBAR sales will, in addition to expanding our wireless gross margin by over 200 basis points further, partially cushion our decline in Q2 revenue from wireless to no more than mid-teens sequentially. Of course, year-on-year, we still project continued growth in our wireless business. 
Moving on to wired infrastructure. Wired revenue declined 7% sequentially and represented 32% of overall revenues. Year-on-year, this grew 59% but closer to 20% without adding in CyOptics. Data center-related demand continued to be strong, particularly for our new-generation, 48-gigabit-per-second fiber optics. However, due to sluggish enterprise demand and soft carrier routing, coupled with the known inventory adjustment at our major networking OEM customer, both our ASICs and parallel optics business declined sequentially compared to the preceding quarter. Now into this mix, we have also aggressively transformed the CyOptics business model from low-margin module revenue in China to higher-margin component sales. Despite this strong demand by service providers, particularly for optical 100G coherent transport solutions, had enabled us to sustain the CyOptics revenue level.
Looking forward to Q2, we believe strength in data spending will continue. In fact, we expect to see the initial ramp of our proprietary bidirectional optical transceivers for simultaneous 10G and 40G transmission, which have been adopted by a major networking customer in their new-generation data center platforms. One network switching remains muted. We expect demand from EDGE routing, as well as high-performance computing, will drive sequential revenue growth for our ASICs. And as a result, we anticipate wired infrastructure revenue to grow mid-single digits on a percentage basis compared with Q1. Importantly, year-on-year, we expect to sustain our revenue growth trajectory in this end market. 
Finally moving on to industrial. Industrial sales declined 11% sequentially, below our expectation at the beginning of the quarter, but nonetheless showed a steady recovery of 6% from the relative bottom of a year ago. Industrial sales represented 19% of our overall revenues. This weaker-than-expected sales were caused largely by our ongoing actions to contract inventory in the channels, which exacerbated this single-digit seasonal decline in distribution resales in this end market. But not all regional geographies behave the same way. As is normal this quarter, we experienced low-single digit declines in North America and Europe. However, Japan continue its industrial recovery based on domestic demand and strong export performance, while Asia remained virtually stable, supported largely by China spending.
Looking to Q2. We expect resales -- industrial resales will rebound by mid-single digits on a percentage basis. We also plan to ship more into distribute channels in anticipation of this improvement in industrial demand. Accordingly, revenue for industrial end market is forecast to grow high-single digits on a percentage basis compared to Q1. By the same token, year-on-year, we anticipate industrial sales will also expand high-single digits. 
To sum up, in Q2 -- in the second fiscal quarter, I should say, we expect product transition at a major OEM in wireless, which will drive consolidated sales down, despite sequential growth in both wired infrastructure and industrial. Accordingly, we're guiding overall revenue to decline between 3% to 6% from that of Q1. Notwithstanding, we expect that the favorable growth trend year-on-year experienced in our 3 end markets during Q1 will persist into Q2. 
With that, let me now turn the call over to Tony for a more detailed review of first quarter fiscal 2014 financials. Tony?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. Before reviewing the first quarter fiscal 2014 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release issued today and is also available at our website at www.avagotech.com. 
Revenue of $709 million in Q1 represents a decrease of 4% from last quarter and an increase of 23% compared to the same quarter a year ago. The sequential decrease was in line with our guidance for the quarter. Revenue from our wireless target market came in slightly better than our expectation, though it was offset by weaker-than-expected revenue from our industrial target market. Revenue from our wired infrastructure target market was roughly in line with our expectation. Foxconn continued to be a greater-than-10% customer. 
Our Q1 gross margin was 52%, which was above our guidance for the quarter, and also higher than the prior quarter. Gross margins improved in some of our product categories, offsetting unfavorable product mix. I would like to highlight that during the quarter, we successfully improved the gross margin of the CyOptics business to our targeted level of approximately mid-40s on a percentage basis, 3 quarters ahead of our original plan. We believe CyOptics gross margin has reached the level to support our overall corporate target and, therefore, we will stop commenting on it separately from this point forward. 
Turning to operating expenses. R&D expenses decreased by $2 million to $98 million, and SG&A decreased by $1 million to $44 million, driving total operating expenses for Q1 to $142 million, $3 million below our guidance. The lower-than-expected operating expenses were primarily due to a curtailment and settlement gain from a change to our U.S. retiree medical plan benefit in the quarter. As a percentage of sales, R&D remained unchanged at 14% and SG&A remained unchanged at 6% of net revenue.
Income from operations for the quarter decreased by $5 million sequentially to $224 million and represented 32% of net revenue. Compared to the $162 million for Q1 of last year, income from operations increased by $62 million, helped primarily by higher revenue. 
Taxes came in at $7 million for Q1, $3 million below our guidance. This was due to a change in the jurisdictional mix of income and expense. 
Q1 net income of $217 million decreased by $10 million from the prior quarter, and Q1 earnings per diluted share of $0.84 was $0.05 lower than Q4. Q4 '13 net income was higher primarily because of an $11 million increase in other income, resulting from a gain on marketable securities. Compared to Q1 of last year, net income was $54 million higher and earnings per diluted share was $0.19 higher. 
Our share-based compensation in Q1 was $24 million. The breakdown of this expense for Q1 includes $3 million in cost of goods sold, $8 million in R&D and $13 million in SG&A. In Q2 2014, we anticipate share-based compensation will be approximately $30 million. And just as a reminder, the company's definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense. 
Moving on to the balance sheet. Our days sales outstanding dropped to 42 days from 52 days in the prior quarter. The decrease was due primarily to the linearity of revenue throughout the quarter, timing of shipments around the holiday season and our collection efforts. 
Our inventory ended at $286 million, a slight increase of $1 million from last quarter. Our wireless inventory remained at an elevated level in anticipation of continued strong demand throughout the year, particularly of our FBAR filter products. Days on hand were 76 days, which increased 5 days from Q4, given the lower revenue during the quarter. 
We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $1.11 billion, and we generated $229 million in operational cash flow. We spent $52 million on capital expenditures. This was below our guidance for the quarter, mainly because of the timing of equipment delivery. For Q2, we expect CapEx to be approximately $70 million, primarily to support our continued build-out of FBAR capacity. 
During the quarter, we repurchased approximately 270,000 shares, which consumed $12 million of cash. The buyback was lower than the prior quarter due to the timing of our negotiations to acquire LSI. On December 31, 2013, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.25 per ordinary share, which consumed $62 million of cash. This dividend was raised by $0.02 from the prior quarter. Since the inception of our dividend program in Q2 2011 to date, we've continued to increase our dividend each quarter. 
Now let me turn to our non-GAAP guidance for the second quarter of fiscal 2014. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions and we do not intend to update this guidance. Total revenue is expected to be down in the range of 3% to 6% from Q1. Gross margin is expected to be 52.5%, plus or minus 1 percentage point. Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $147 million. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $7 million. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 261 million shares. 
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, please open up the call for questions.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Jim Schneider of -- once again from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: You mentioned a couple of mixed improvements within wireless and also within the wired business from CyOptics. Can you maybe talk a little bit about how much of the relative and improvement was from each of those 2 buckets? And whether we're kind of now at a level where that mix, at least in the wireless, is expected to kind of sustain itself in the current place?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Yes. So I think the mix, we've seen improvement in the wireless side is sustainable. It's definitely things that you can get that as the FBAR mix and so forth. And then obviously, as Hock mentioned very directly, at CyOptics, we've moved several steps away from the subassembly business into more of a component business, which is helpful to the bottom line as well.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, regarding your comments, Hock, around the inventory levels at distributors, it sounds like there is a little bit more of a bleed-off in inventories kind of across the board in the January quarter. You'll be expecting to refill that a little bit in April. Is that refill happening pretty much across the board geographically or there are things going on differently in the different regions?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Jim, they are in different regions, absolutely. And -- but in -- if we talk industrial, as I assume you are referring to in this question, we are seeing refill a lot in Japan where there's a fairly strong industrial recovery. We're also seeing that in Europe where, after the season -- and the holidays season last quarter, things are picking up and resale is showing very strong signs. Those are 2 specific areas we are talking about. Industrial in -- as I mentioned, in China, continues to be stable, slightly up, but nothing dramatic, but very stable at a significant level. Having said that, for channel inventory in general, we are seeing very strong resale. And because of that refilling too, in China, particularly with respect, not so much for industrial, in China, as much as wireless products for the white box makers in China.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Hock, you guys have seen some uplifts for FBAR in terms of margin mix and wireless. Outside of that, could you share any thoughts in terms of what we're seeing just yesterday in terms of industry consolidation and what that might mean for pricing and margins in the broader business within RF?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Well, there are quite a few players in RF business, as you well know. And I assume you are referring to the announced merger of RFMD and TriQuint. And it's -- we know Bob and Ralph very well, strong -- good guys, good managers. And we have very strong managers. So I think the consolidation would be positive for the industry as a whole, certainly puts more -- possibly more stronger competition. But we always welcome competition, as I said, because we compete largely on the basis of technology more than anything else.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Got it. And then as a follow-up, any incremental thoughts you could share on LSI, specifically, just confidence levels in terms of achieving the cost synergies you first laid out?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Really, it's too early at this point. I mean, we're still awaiting all regulatory approvals and not to mention the shareholder approval of LSI, which will happen some time in April. So we really do not expect deal -- the deal to close before early May, probably maybe even later. And so at this stage, it would definitely be too early for us to know -- understand and know whether our assumptions in driving this deal still holds true at all.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya, Bank of America.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Hock, the question is on the wireless business, obviously, does perform very well in the last few years. But when I look at the guidance you're giving for the April quarter, it suggests sort of mid-single digit or so year-on-year growth. Now I understand the transition at your largest customer. But how is it that of the need for FBAR is going up, yet you are seeing this deceleration in sales. Is this just sort of a temporary pause when the growth driver is really your largest customer and as the mix shifts towards more to China and other customers? Or are you still comfortable with the long-term sort of double-digit growth trajectory possible in this business?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: To get right to the nut of your question, yes. We are still very comfortable with double-digit year-on-year growth. As I was very careful to articulate in each case, year-on-year, we still show -- which is on a quarter-on-quarter basis, year-on-year, we still show double-digit growth. The interesting thing we are experiencing, and I mentioned that a lot in my last -- in the last earnings call and I don't -- and I'm -- is simply that as the OEM industry consolidates, revenues within each year, as we go 1 quarter to the other within each year, goes through sharp movements because of product transitions of those larger OEMs now in smartphones in the marketplace. And so you do -- we do -- and by the way, our content keeps increasing in those OEMs, which exacerbates it even further. But what we do see is fairly sharp changes in revenues quarter-on-quarter during the year. But if you look at -- if you look -- trend it over the -- from 1 year to the other, you will see very clearly that we are able to sustain double-digit, year-on-year growth, which is really what matters because within each in a year, you will see the other handset OEM launch their products at different times. And because of that, we go through fairly sharp upticks as well as fairly sharp declines, as we move from one quarter as we did from Q1 to Q2 in this current year. And we will probably see another cycle of movements as we move to Q3 and Q4 this year when the large OEM launches its new generation of phones.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Got it, that's very helpful, Hock. And as a follow-up, I think you mentioned that you are starting to see the surge in your China FBAR adoption. Is there a way to quantify how much that is? So outside of your top 2 sort of Tier 1 customers, is there a way to size how much that white box China market is demanding FBAR? Or is it too early to provide that quantification?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: You hit it right on because I was going to say, it's -- it is a surge. And because it's not just one OEM in China that's launching LTE-enabled phones -- smartphones. It's multiple OEMs at the same time rushing into this market. And as you all know out there, China 4G or LTE is just a big thing this year -- since the beginning of this year. And it's not just handset that's happening. It's infrastructure -- wireless infrastructure that's been built out, rolling out in China on LTE and shouldn't surprise us all that -- because of that smartphones are coming out LTE-enabled, which are low cost, even by China standards, and -- but then are LTE-enabled. And it really proves a point that we have been announcing all the time in our FBAR thesis, which is FBAR is used based on technology requirement, not based on whether they are high end or low end. It is really based on technology requirements and there are some bands, particularly in China, that do require, very much so, FBAR in order to achieve its performance. And because of that, we are seeing those designs and quite a considerable amount of those designs, which are driving quite a bit of our FBAR revenue from that angle. Having said that, our more traditional markets of the large, branded smartphone OEMs continue to adopt for the same reason the Chinese white box OEMs are adopting more and more designs that uses FBAR, though a lot of them relate to front-end modules that encompasses both the FBARs and filters, as well as the associated power amplifiers from an not just one band, from multiple bands, within your phones.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: All right. Just one last one, high CapEx is -- could be a good news or bad news story. The question is -- it was about 8% of sales for you in the last 4 quarters. Is there a point at which it starts to taper off or just that the demand for FBAR is there so CapEx could stay at sort of these levels?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Well, again, Vivek, we talked about CapEx being somewhat of a challenge this year. But again, we're only investing with line-of-sight capacity that we need for either, as Hock mentioned, either the large OEMs or some of these other surge we're having. So we're going to be very selective. We're getting great return on the CapEx in the FBAR fab. And these surges, in some ways, you can have it as an indication of our confidence in the future.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: We -- in other words, we laid our investment behind demand CapEx. And it's always a challenge, therefore, for us to meet those demand, I'll be honest, which also relates to why, as Tony pointed out in his remarks on inventory, we run our fabs very full.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis, Barclays.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: This is Chris Hemmelgarn on for Blayne. Just a quick question first on your wireless expectations, just kind of what you're baking in -- what you're Q2 guidance bakes in there in terms of -- how steep of a decline are you really seeing at the one wireless customer you highlighted? What are the puts and takes there and -- versus what your wireless infra business?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: To answer you directly, we don't make any specific remarks on any particular customer, Chris. I'm sorry about that. I prefer not to answer that. We generally don't comment on any particular customer. We love them too much.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Not a problem, I had to try. Moving on from that. There were a couple of announcements out of some BAW competitors out of Japan. I'm just kind of interested in whether you guys still really see that as predominantly just you and TriQuint competing for those sockets? Are you really any seeing any progress from the rest of the competition that's largely trailed you guys to this point?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Well, I mean, it's not new -- not a new information as you'll know that there are SAW makers who put in temperature compensation to try to improve the performance and try to achieve closer to what BAW or FBAR performance achieves, and we constantly see that and because they constantly improve, as we try to improve. So it's a typical technological race. They improve, we try to improve more. And if we're already ahead of the game, it makes our improvement much better. But they still [indiscernible]. And in terms of other players, then just ourselves and TriQuint trying to get into the BAW business, oh, yes, that had -- has happened. It's not the first time. And that continues to happen. It's something -- nothing new. We have not seen for the last few years. But see, a big part of where we are today is not just the technology in terms of evolution of FBAR or BAW, as you put it generically. We are on, as I mentioned, on our current 8th generation, moving to our 9th generation. Nobody comes even close at this point. And as long as we keep making the investments we are making, we not only are continuing to be ahead of the game technologically on our FBAR, but in terms of capacity to try to address a very fast-expanding market. We  are also, I believe, quite way ahead of anybody else.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: We have a question from the line of Romit Shah, Nomura.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: This Sanjay for Romit Shah. Hock, one question on TD-LTE RAM. I just wanted to get a sense of what the content is and what are the bands FBAR is being used across OEMs. Do you see this usage fairly similar across OEMs or you see there are differences in terms of band coverage and content?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: It depends on the country. But if you're referring to China, they're multiple and not the same OEMs will apply the same band. Depends on how they architect the phones, particularly. But it's a whole spectrum in the range of 2.3, 2.4 gigahertz, all the way to 2.8, 2.7 gigahertz in that range. And within it, as you know, there's been 38, 40, 41, WiFi, WiMAX, and it's all -- it's a combination of all the foregoing.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: And as a follow-up, you mentioned increasing competition from the merger of TriQuint and RF Micro. I was just wondering, you mentioned that you're technologically much ahead, moving from 8th to 9th generation. What are the -- some of the dimensions you could see competition from these guys, if not from a technology point of view?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Let me rephrase what I said earlier, and I apologize if I misinformed you, guys. We already have competition -- good and healthy competition from RFMD, TriQuint as we do from Skyworks, Energy JIG [ph] and a few others. So it is still there. And if 2 of our competitors shows to merge to perhaps present a more united front, more power to them, frankly. And we will continue to see that competition, and I don't see there'll be any abatement of that competition that -- with their merger. And I think it will keep ongoing. And as I said, all -- what we do is we -- as I said, we compete on a kind of different dimension from many of our competitors. We compete purely on products that we believe we can do much better -- much, much better than they can, and we do not compete on products that are commoditized. And that strategy on our side still will not change.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: The next question comes from line of JoAnne Feeney, ABR Investment Strategy.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Question for you on the competition and your response to your strategy. So TriQuint, RF Micro combined, Skyworks, Qualcomm have all now announced integrated end-to-end RF solutions. And so I guess, I'm wondering whether you plan to release something along those lines or whether you feel like Avago's best strategy is not to go that route and to stick with products that are more FBAR-focused and take advantage perhaps of some discrete FBAR opportunities that the other competitors simply cannot satisfy.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Well, our strategy is probably not that distinctly different, JoAnne, in the sense that, yes, we only see FBAR as our real differentiator sustainably. We're not wrong there, really. And that's why we put in huge amount of investments. We also put in investment in doing power amplifiers because that's what it takes to sell FBAR many times. And it's a very -- and it's -- it changes depending on the generation. It changes depending on the architecture. So it's not one single particular architecture in RF that makes -- that is pretty much etched in concrete. We vary -- it varies. So many times we sell discrete FBAR and we love to do that. But if we have to, we sell those so-called end-to-end solutions as you pointed. We call it front-end module. We just don't have the transceivers, I guess. But on an RF basis, we do cover the full gamut between the antenna to the baseband transceiver. But if you're talking about things like SkyOne and -- or RF360 by Qualcomm, we don't specifically go into that yet. Doesn't mean we will never. We keep an open mind, as I said, and we are very opportunistic based on the fact that our simple -- our single strategy is we do products that can differentiate ourselves and performs distinctly. And we can in any socket. We'll probably won't even participate in that socket.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: And then -- and as a follow-up, you mentioned you're growing success with the midrange and low-end smartphone makers, particularly in China. I'm wondering if in that context, number one, you could describe for us where you think your second half growth is coming from in terms of, say, increase in dollar contents, higher units in these midrange phones. And perhaps, if you have any sense of this, what percentage of your wireless revenues you think might shift towards these midrange phones and away from the high end where you've done so well?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Thanks, JoAnne. Hey, you are really reading too much in what I'm saying, and maybe it's my mistake. I was actually trying and doing a very unprofessional victory lap about the fact that, hey, finally, we got into low-end phones in China and that's because of FBAR. Because, as you know, we have never -- we have not participated much in those low-end phones in China because of price and because of inability to differentiate. Finally, we did and it's because of FBAR, which we've been talking about for years about the fact that it's technology that drives its usage more than the price points of smartphones. We've finally proven that. That's all I'm saying. And unfortunately, this seems to be leading you to a path that says, "Well, now tell me, when -- how much is it going to drive your business?" Well, a bit too early to tell, I'd be honest, JoAnne, because it depends on how successful those LTE-enabled white box phones are going to be in China. And I can't really tell because the surge of it is just happening. It could be a one-quarter wonder for all I know. I don't really know. I hope it isn't. And if it can sustain, it'd be great for us. But what drives our business on a consistent basis, I think, are also those branded large OEMs out there that we continue to be very, very well positioned. And we see that continuing over the foreseeable future..

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. So that means that, that double-digit growth you're anticipating, the year-over-year double-digit growth for wireless, the majority of that's been -- is being driven by content gains, as opposed to the unit growth?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Yes, it is. You're correct, JoAnne. It's been content. And year-on-year, with the same large OEMs that we deal with, our -- because of increasing band -- number of bands and increasing complexity of architecture in bands like carrier aggregation coming in and, as we mentioned a few other things before, content keep increasing and we are able to grow our content year-on-year in those generation of phones.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Doug Freedman, RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: If you could focus a little bit on a segment we haven't talked much about yet and that would be the industrial segment, I'm a little surprised to hear about your bullishness, giving -- we keep hearing that the China end market is seeing softening PMI results, but yet I believe you're still fairly exposed to the China market on the industrial side. Can you talk to us a little bit about why you're feeling as confident about that market coming back?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Okay, that's a very good question. That's a very interesting question for me. And I try to put in some comments. I'll tell you what we're seeing right now. I don't know what's going to happen the rest of the year, to be honest. It's hard to figure it out. But in enterprise, the transceiver business overall is kind of -- the optical transceiver business has been flattish and no surprise, as some of the OEMs out there have been saying that there may be winners and losers among the lot. But broadly, I think the market is flattish. And the way we try to play in this market now is what we have always been trying to do, which is pick out opportunities that are -- that we can produce fairly proprietary products for and right on the coattails of those customers who adopt our proprietary designs and use that to push their overall systems. And as I pointed out earlier, we've started last year with 40G and that's more of a standard product. But we were about the only guy who could do it at that time and do it for extend -- relatively longer distances to be applied in data centers. And we have been selling it very well, and we continue to sell it very well. That's one of our drivers. The other thing that is also happening now is we just launched and are ramping up another proprietary fiber optics that is bidirectional. What that really does is applicable, particularly, for data centers where we can with our transceivers, our customers or their customers or our OEMs can run using the same infrastructure of OM3 fiber optic cables that have already been laid out in an existing legacy data center, just change the transceiver and suddenly transform the transceiver from running 10 gigabit to 40 gigabit by just putting in new transceivers and boxes. That's the one -- that's the new product we launched and that's what I mentioned earlier in my remarks about transceivers that can simultaneously do 10 gigabit, as well as 40 gigabit. That's the bidirectional product we launched. We're depending on those kind of proprietary system to give us an edge and gain us share to grow. But as far as the broader market is concerned, what we're seeing now is fairly flat and sluggish, be it switching, routing market -- be it switching or routing market.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Okay, great. And then sort of on the SerDes side then, can you talk about the growth opportunity you're seeing for the year at this point? headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Well, our big thing in ASICs is our SerDes. We have definitely very, very good ASICs, very proven ASICs. And there are not too many people out there who can do those kind of ASICs and run it all the way to 28 gigabit per second, which is what we and our current generation of products out there in designs are doing now. And that's really our edge, our differentiation in a lot of the opportunities we go against. Of course, the other side to it is we are very tested and we have very good skills in integrating, not just the SerDes, but the IP cost into one complex micron digital chip that we do for ASICs for our customers. And we're very good at doing that. So we continue to driving that. And frankly, on our ASIC business, we're very linked to the customers we deal with and we deal with only a handful of large OEM customers. And as they succeed, so do we. If they don't grow as much, we don't grow as much either. But that's pretty much where we stand right now. And so we've -- in terms of -- and we are very much focused on the enterprise networking business, though we do some of it in high-performance computing. And what we're seeing now is high-performance computing is doing very good currently. So that's providing the engine of growth for us. As far as ASICs into enterprise networking, largely in the switches and all that, growth here is okay. And over the last few years, we've been growing at 20% a year. We expect close to that this year as well. But if not, something that ramps up fairly rapidly.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: Okay, great. If I could sneak one last one in on FBAR. Obviously, as the bands proliferate out there because of LTE, a number of them are in certain higher frequency ranges. What I'm trying to understand is how many of them might be sort of on the border there between what SAW and TC-SAW can do or the low-end BAW players? So how much of -- how much of the -- or how many of the bands that are going out there are really sort of right along the border where it might be more competitive versus high end where you guys with your 8th or 9th generation can really differentiate and be sure to capture share?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q1 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2014
componenttext: It's a hard question to answer because, yes, there -- I'm sure there are bands that are on the edge, as you put it. But it's -- but some of these bands are on the edge because of how they are architected in any phone system. If, for instance, they are stuck next to certain other bands and certain other functions that may interfere with their performance easily, certainly, the band that is on the margin may become not on the margin any longer. Equally, the other direction, if you put a -- even if you put a band that is not so on the margin but in a very clean environment, and that doesn't happen too often, might get away with temperature-compensated SAW filters. Doesn't happen too often, though. But it's hard. It is -- this as not a -- it's not deterministic. It's very under-deterministic, depending on the system and the architecture of each of the handset. But what the broader picture is evolving is that as you put in more bands and as phones carry around more bands, and some of these bands are harder and harder, and even if all bands are on the margin, when you put a bunch of them together, they all become non-marginal. They become tough. And as more of that happens, the trend towards FBAR, as I've always said, will continue to move up.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you, Ashish. Good afternoon, everyone. Now we're going to start today, as we always do, by reviewing recent business highlights in our end markets. And then, Tony will provide summary of our second quarter fiscal 2014 fiscal results. 
Before we do that, a couple of housekeeping items. As you all know, we closed the LSI acquisition on May 6, 1 day into our fiscal Q3. And I'm very pleased to welcome LSI's employees, customers and partners to Avago. Since then, we have been hard at work integrating the 2 companies. And accordingly, any comments made on fiscal third quarter and beyond will apply to the combined Avago/LSI businesses. Q2 commentary will, of course, only apply to classic Avago. 
Also, earlier today, Seagate announced they will be acquiring the LSI flash businesses, which include the standard flash controllers and the PCI Express flash adapter product lines for $450 million in cash. We are divesting this LSI product lines, as they do not strategically fit with our long-term business model. The impact from this divestiture to our total revenue, on an Avago/LSI combined basis, is not material. 
Okay. Starting with our Q3 fiscal quarter, our mix of revenue will change and will now include a new end market we call enterprise storage, in addition to the previously defined Avago wireless, wired infrastructure and industrial markets. I will provide additional color on the changes in the end market discussion. 
Revenue for our second quarter was $701 million, and represented a decline of 1% from last quarter and an increase of 25% from the same quarter a year ago. Q2 revenue came in higher than the upper end of our guidance, and the primary driver of our better-than-expected revenue performance was very strong wireless shipments into Korean and Chinese handset OEMs. 
Let me now proceed to provide much more color on each of these end markets, starting with wireless. The composition of our wireless end market remains unchanged, post the LSI acquisition, basically comes from Avago classic. And for fiscal Q2, revenue from wireless came in significantly above our expectations and was flat sequentially compared to our prior expectations for mid-teen decline on a percentage basis. Wireless represented 50% of our total revenue, and on a year-over-year basis, wireless grew 25%. 
As mentioned during our Q1 call, we had expected our Q2 revenue to decline sequentially, as we work through the normal annual product transition in a large North American OEM customer. While we did experience that anticipated product-transition-related decline, we were able to fully offset that decrease with a strong product ramp at another smartphone OEM and strong demand from LTE-enabled Chinese smartphones. We are also achieving high penetration with these Chinese OEMs through our industry-leading FBAR technology. The growth in FBAR-related revenue helped us to continue to expand our gross margin. 
Looking at Q3 fiscal 2014, and clearly, this end market is only classic Avago, we expect mid-single digit sequential growth in our wireless business with the beginning of a ramp from a North American smartphone customer, as they transition to their next-generation platform. And we continue to also see very strong demand for our FBAR-related products from the Chinese LTE smartphone OEM. We also expect to see additional Avago content for handsets enabled by our FBAR technology and taking advantage of the expected increase in RF content across both traditional high-end smartphones, as well as even entry-level solutions. For Q3, revenues from our wireless end market will be a little over 25% of our total revenues, which would have included the impact of the LSI acquisition. 
Moving on to wired infrastructure, for fiscal Q2, in which we talk only about Avago classic, wired revenue decreased 4% sequentially, performing below our expectations at the beginning of the quarter and represented 31% of overall revenues. However, we continue to see a fair amount of strength in this end market as, on a year-over-year basis, we still grew 43%. ASICs was flat sequentially, as data center switching remains relatively soft, but we're starting to see a rebound in a major -- at a major data networking OEM. We saw a sequential decline in our fiber optics with slower-than-expected shipments for our 40G products, which are also influenced by data-center-switching softness. 
Please note too, that starting fiscal Q3, in addition to fiber optics and SerDes-based ASICs, our wired infrastructure end market will now also include LSI's ASICs, as well as standard x-year-based products. In this regard, we expect Q3 revenues from a combined wired infrastructure end market to be a little over 1/4 of our total revenues. Looking forward, we expect strength on a number of fronts. We expect a significant ramp in our ASIC revenue from shipments into base stations, as well as enterprise and data center switching platforms. ASIC increases will come from both Avago and LSI design wins. And we are expecting a recovery in fiber optics as it relates to enterprise switching. We believe that a combination of LSI and Avago positions us extremely well to take advantage of next-generation data center switching and LTE transitions and network upgrades on the wireless infrastructure side.
Onto enterprise storage. This is a new market for Avago, addressed by LSI's hard disk drives and servers and storage connectivity product lines. Accordingly, for Q2, we have no discussion as it relates to Avago classic. For Q3, however, we expect to continue the momentum and leadership LSI had established across all the storage product lines, and expect some strength in Q3. For hard disk drives, against a backdrop of a fairly stable market, especially in our focus areas of 3.5-inch and enterprise SaaS, we expect to continue to benefit from our strong design win positions in 3 channels and pre-amps across all hard drive OEMs. 
Our server and storage connectivity business, which includes our SaaS and rate silicon adapter and software solutions, are now entering the seasonally second -- strongest second half of the calendar year for the server and external storage markets. We remain very enthusiastic with our progress in 12G SaaS design wins and ramps across multiple OEM customers. And we expect Q3 revenues from enterprise storage to be approximately 1/3 of our total revenues. For now, we expect enterprise storage will be the largest end market for us.
And finally, moving on to industrial. Fiscal Q2 industrial resales were very strong in the quarter, with double-digit sequential growth on a percentage basis, which was in line with our expectation for this end market. We saw strength, especially in Europe and Japan; however, we reduced shipments to our distributors to reduce inventory levels in the channel. This resulted in industrial sales increasing only 2% sequentially during Q2, but way below what we have guided at the beginning of the quarter, but up 3% from a year ago. Industrial sales represented 19% of our overall revenue in Q2. In Q3, though, we expect to replenish inventory, the low level of inventory, at many of our distributors, to support expected growth in the high-single digit level, sequentially, as a result of continuing worldwide recovery in industrial activity.
Now starting Q3, we will also include in the industrial the LSI intellectual property licensing business. Combined with this, our Q3 revenues will be approximately 1/8 of total revenues in this segment. 
In summary, for Q3, here's how we would see our business. The beginning of a strong product ramp in wireless, a rebound in wired infrastructure and continued stability and slight growth in enterprise storage and industrial. We expect overall revenue for fiscal quarter Q3, therefore, to come in between $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion. As you know, this is the first quarter for the combined Avago/LSI businesses, and integration activities are still progressing but progressing very well. Our restructuring activities to achieve forecast annual cost synergies of $200 million have just kicked off, but we remain very much on track to achieve these by the end of our fiscal 2015, the first full fiscal year after closing. We are also working to drive the combined LSI Avago businesses long-term towards a non-GAAP operating margin model that is consistent with the Avago classic business model. 
With that, let me now turn the call over to Tony for a more detailed review of our second quarter fiscal 2014 financials.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you, Hock, and good afternoon, everyone. Before reviewing the second quarter fiscal 2014 financial results, I want to remind you that my comments today will focus primarily on our non-GAAP results. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP data is included with the earnings release issued today and is also available on our website at www.avagotech.com. 
Revenue of $701 million in Q2 represents a decrease of 1% from last quarter and an increase of 25% compared to the same quarter a year ago. Overall, Q2 revenue came in higher than the upper end of our guidance. Revenue from our wireless target market came in better than our expectation, though it was offset by weaker-than-expected revenue from our wired infrastructure and industrial end markets. 
Foxconn and Samsung were greater-than-10% customers in fiscal Q2. Our Q2 gross margin was 54%, which was above our guidance for the quarter and also higher than the prior quarter, primarily due to a higher-than-expected FBAR revenues, which have favorable gross margins. 
Turning to operating expenses, R&D expenses increased by $3 million, to $101 million, and SG&A increased by $3 million, to $47 million, driving total operating expenses for Q2 to $148 million, or $1 million above our guidance. As a percentage of sales, R&D remained unchanged at 14% and SG&A was 7% of net revenue. 
Income from operations for the quarter increased by $9 million, sequentially, to $233 million, and represented 33% of net revenue. Compared to the $158 million for Q2 of last year, income from operations increased by $75 million, helped by higher revenues and better gross margins. Taxes came in at $9 million for Q2, $2 million above our guidance. This is primarily due to higher income than forecast, as well as a change in the jurisdictional mix of income and expense.
Q2 net income of $223 million increased by $6 million from the prior quarter, and Q2 earnings per diluted share was $0.85 or $0.01 higher than Q1. Compared to Q2 of last year, net income was $70 million higher and earnings per diluted share was $0.24 higher. 
Our share-based compensation in Q2 was $30 million, the breakdown of the expense for Q2 includes: $3 million in cost of goods sold; $10 million in R&D; and $17 million in SG&A. In Q3 2014, we anticipate share-based compensation will be approximately $79 million, and this includes the impact from the LSI acquisition. Just as a reminder, our definition of non-GAAP net income excludes share-based compensation expense.
Moving on to the balance sheet. Our days sales outstanding remained at 42 days, same as the prior quarter, as we observed stable revenue linearity throughout the quarter. Our inventory ended at $301 million, an increase of $15 million from our last quarter. Our wireless inventory increased in anticipation of a continued strong demand throughout the remainder of the calendar year, particularly for our FBAR products. 
Days on hand were 86 days, which increased 10 days from Q1 due to this planned inventory build. We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $1.3 billion and we generated $251 million in operational cash flow. 
We spent $73 million on capital expenditures. For Q3, we expect CapEx to be approximately $125 million, which primarily relates to spending to support our continued build-out of FBAR capacity and also the impact from the LSI businesses, which include a campus rationalization. 
During the quarter, we did not repurchase any shares in anticipation of completing the LSI acquisition, which closed on May 6. Our 2013 share repurchase program has expired, and the board has not, as yet, authorized any new share repurchases while we digest the LSI transaction. However, it is something that we and the board look at regularly. 
On March 31, 2013, we paid a quarterly cash dividend of $0.27 per ordinary share, which consumed $68 million of cash. The dividend was raised by $0.02 from the prior quarter. Since the inception of our dividend program in Q2 of 2011 to date, we have continued to increase our dividend each quarter. 
Now let me turn to our non-GAAP guidance for the third quarter of fiscal 2014. This guidance reflects our current assessment of business conditions and we do not intend to update this guidance. Our Q3 guidance includes the LSI acquisition, which closed on the second day of the quarter. This guidance is not adjusted for the business divestiture announced earlier today. 
Total revenue is expected to be in the range of $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion. Gross margin is expected to be 55%, plus or minus 1 percentage point. Operating expenses are estimated to be approximately $386 million. Taxes are forecasted to be approximately $20 million. Interest expense is expected to be approximately $54 million. And finally, the diluted share count forecast is for 276 million shares. 
That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator, please open up the call for questions.

Here's a bit less predictable, we're not looking at this miss in the Q2 on, obviously, on fiber optics, which is what this is, because our ASIC business sustained. And on my remarks on fiber optics, it's simply because at the leading edge, especially on 40G, fiber -- 40G interconnects, fiber transceiver interconnects, which is where we largely see a miss, and that's probably because it is state-of-the-art data center build-outs that require the use of those 40G. Hence, our expected rebound in Q3, what we missed in Q2.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Great. And then just one follow-up, Tony, one for you, on the OpEx level, that $386 million you're guiding to, how should we think about that going forward? If you want to include the divestiture announcement that you put today into the answer or otherwise, just what's the sort of trend as you think about that in achieving that $200 million cost synergy that you've prior set out as a target?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Well, as Hock mentioned, we're off to a good start, so we believe that there is, easily, several million that we're going to realize in Q3, and you'll see kind of an acceleration in Q4 because those would be the quarters where, essentially, people costs are fully gone for a full quarter. So we're really confident on the acceleration on removal of costs. And as we mentioned, most of it is going to come from the R&D and SG&A line. Now I won't comment at all on the divestiture just yet, but we'll break that down in the future, as we complete the sale and so forth.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: So simply put, fiscal fourth quarter OpEx should be down, sale aside?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Yes. Again, with a small caveat that I always give you, Ross, is that, for example, if we over-perform on some of our bonus metrics that sometimes, in Q4, we have a little bit of a catch-up there. But everything else held equal, we should trend down, over time, quite significantly.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: I think we did indicate to you guys in our last call, I think, that you should expect to see the OpEx on our first $200 million, therefore go down by $50 million a quarter by the middle of fiscal '15 or by the end of fiscal '15, I believe. And we are very much on track on that.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Yes. And we always said, Ross, is we'll have some immediate benefit. We'll go through a flat spot, kind of, quarters 3 and 4. And then we'll see this re-acceleration as we complete some of our integration.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: And we don't expect -- and that would not include the divestitures we are announcing here.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Right.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: A question on the gross margin. The core Avago came in above the high end of your previous targets, and then LSI will be a little accretive to that. Can you just talk about the sustainability in terms of some of the things you're seeing from mix in wireless, as well as maybe the growth in comm and how you're thinking about gross margin, longer term?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Well, I think, we've always commented that we've had the benefit the last couple of quarters of a very full fab in wireless, and good strong demand on our higher wireless product, namely, FBAR. We believe that's something that can continue well throughout the calendar year. However, we do have some CapEx coming online, so depreciation in the fab will go up slightly. But we've seen utilization in the fab is pretty much pegged at 100%, and even as we add capacity throughout the year. So we think the tailwinds to our gross margin is still pretty good, mostly driven by kind of our wireless, especially, wireless mix. And then the overall wireless division is, again, closing that gap on the corporate average pretty quickly as well. So we're very positive on those things. And the rest of the businesses are holding up well. I'd say it's mostly a wireless focus right now.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Got it. And then as my follow-up, Hock, on the comm business, outside of the variability, quarter-to-quarter, in the fiber side, do you have a view in terms of where you think we are on the 10G to 40G upgrade cycle?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: On the 10G to 40G, for enterprises -- traditional enterprises, still very early. For the large data center guys, with some exceptions, very few -- with certain few exceptions, again, it's still very early in that upgrade cycle. Hence, the -- once we get to see some of the variability on this particular 40G product line that we so position ourself very well. And -- but, probably, we'll see more sustainable 40G, going forward, over the next 6 to 12 months.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Romit Shah with Nomura.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: I want to go back to the announcement this morning. Hock, just the sale of the LSI flash business, I'm curious what you think this means for your HDD business?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: As we said -- I mean, that's -- I'm not sure what you're trying to address here. But they are kind of very different businesses.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: But just what we're seeing in the marketplace...

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Sorry?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: What we're seeing the marketplace is that SSDs are replacing HDDs where things like speed, power, durability are important considerations in both notebook and desktop platforms. To the extent that you don't have an SSD product line, I would think that this would negatively impact your HDD business.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: I think there is some level of -- Romit, you're correct in that respect that flash -- or SSDs, that is, are replacing HDDs in certain segments of the market. One big part of it is, obviously, notebooks, which, fortunately, LSI is very little represented, very little, if not, not at all represented, hence, the emphasis has been on 3.5-inch to SaaS hard drives. But -- and also in certain parts of data centers where you want really very fast -- or very good IOPS or latency access, that's an element of our replacement in that regard there. We see that and we do support that -- those enterprise markets through customized flash controllers that we developed for specific OEM customers of ours. That continues to happen and we continue to be able to participate in that. What we are moving out of by this divestiture is the merchant market for flash controllers on SSDs which is -- a big part of it, will be, obviously, in the client market and which we do not see our position to be very strategic in the first place.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Okay. And then, Tony, just a question on stock option expense. If I look at Avago's standalone, it's been about $30 million per quarter, that's about $0.10 to $0.12, and with the inclusion of LSI, it jumps up to about $80 million, which is more like $0.30. So how do we model that going forward? Is the $0.30, over time, going to come down? How should we think about stock option expense going forward?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Again, there's 2 pieces in that $79 million, there's the traditional Avago piece, which we had a grant in March. And so if we were to strip that out separately, it probably -- would increased probably from $30 million to, roughly, $40 million. And then for the LSI piece, is the remainder, so $39 million. Now that is impacted as well by the early exits of certain executives where they're accelerated. So we will see that trend down pretty significantly, pretty quickly, over time, to maybe a run rate of something closer to 20 in out quarters like 5 or 6 quarters out. However, I still qualify that because again, we need to bring on the LSI people onto our plans for stock comp and so forth. So I don't really have a real long term, but the $79 million is really somewhat of an anomaly for kind of this quarter and maybe next because we have this huge overhang from some of the exits that we have to pay for.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of JoAnne Feeney from ABR Investment.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: I was hoping we could go back into the wired discussion a little bit. The 40G transition that's underway, I'm wondering if you have orders in place and backlog in place that gives you that confidence that you talked about a little bit earlier. And then also what you're seeing on the 100G transition as well?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: On the 100G for short reach, which is basically for data centers as opposed to transport or long reach. On 100G short reach, it's still very early. It won't probably happen for at least couple of years for most of the data center guys or enterprise guys in -- on transporting short-reach data. 40G is happening right now. And yes, we do have substantial backlog on those businesses.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Okay. And then on the wireless backhaul and wireless infrastructure, more generally. We've heard that, that strengthened and you've confirmed that. I'm just wondering how much visibility you have there. There's some concern that we might get a short burst of spending and then a sharp decline. Do you have any insight into how that might play out for the rest of the year?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Not really. A large of part of that is happening -- a large part of this growth driver is obviously happening in China, as the Chinese carriers build out their 4G networks. And in so doing, at the same time, I believe they're obviously pushing the use of that network by being very aggressive in promoting, they call it terminals, I guess we call it handsets, devices in -- that are 4G-enabled. All that is happening, which is a big part of driving our wireless business, which we announced Q2 and which we continue to see strength in Q3 because of the proliferation of LTE-based handsets in China, both from local Chinese OEMs, as well as benefiting some of the global OEMs who sell into China. And we see both of that happening. But as far as the infrastructure side, it depends. There are some strength in it, especially on the backhaul, and it seems to move from backhaul to front end on the base station side, and we have -- and we've seen that vary quarter-to-quarter. As far as how long they will keep sustaining the rest of this year? I don't know. We can only hear -- have hearsay, but in terms of actual line of sight, we probably don't see it more than one quarter at a time.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Doug Freedman with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Hock, can you maybe give us a little bit of your view on the growth outlook of each of these segments now that we've got the combined company?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Okay. Broadly speaking, and we think that's long-term, and long-term being 6 months, perhaps 1 year. Well, 1 year, say, realistically. What we see the highest growth drivers for our business is in wireless and wired, wired infrastructure. As in wireless, the reasons are quite obvious, is that 4G comes into play more and more, but what's also more clear is that as it comes into play, not just in China, now that North America is very 4G-enabled but more slowly, beginning into Europe and other places, we see content in handsets, smartphones, in particular, increasing. And we are rising more than unit growth, content growth in smartphones very strongly. And very short-term, technically, the ramp this current quarter, the beginning of the ramp this current quarter of our largest North American OEM customer is just tip of the iceberg in our view. So it would drive our wireless business very nicely, I think, over the next 12 months by line of sight. On wired, we see a combination that helps, some of it relates to China too. As I mentioned, as we've -- I talked along in -- to replying to earlier question, we see that 4G phenomenon, the conversion, to be a sustainable thing. Quarterly, you might see some variability, as we talked about. But over the next 12 months, we're very well-positioned, as evidenced by the size of our designs, but also the size of our existing backlog, by the way. That will drive our fiber business and will also drive a whole generation of SerDes-based ASICs that we and LSI, combined, have been able to secure in data center switching, as I articulated in my notes. That, coupled with more of a local phenomenon in China networks, metro networks and backhaul, especially in areas in excess to, I'm going to say, where we have a very strong position. We all see that, again, China build-outs of their expanded networks, especially in fiber access and fiber networks through backhaul as augmenting the strength in our wired infrastructure business. We see that today, and we see that continuing through the end of this year in China. So those 2 would be businesses we see growing probably at least in the double digits over the next 12 months. Against that, we see stable businesses, and by stable, I mean business that may grow in the single digit, mid-single digits, likely, in both enterprise storage and industrial. Low- to mid-single digits. So we have an interesting combination of 2 businesses, 2 end markets that will grow double digits and 2 -- that as we see now, are very stable, if not stably growing. So the endpoint of it all, when you combine all 4 together in a fairly balanced mix, is a business that probably is what we had forecasted before, which was a business that will grow in the high-single digits to, probably, low-double digits over the next 12 months.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Great. And if I could, can you talk a little bit about the mix of business that you're seeing in the wireless segment in terms of, maybe, diversity? And any trigger points that you may have that are required to support it from a capacity standpoint?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: We -- I do not equate wireless to diversity now, but eventually. They're not -- the consolidation -- 80% -- more than 80% of wireless business, about 80%, relates to handsets, and the bulk of it in handsets are triggered, are tied to FBAR, one way or the other. Power amplifiers that are put into front-end modules, with filters, FBAR filters, or whatever, but it is. And as you know, the handset businesses, especially smartphone business, has been very much consolidated. We are very well represented, by the way, in spite of the consolidation. But it is not that diversified in that regard. The positive side of looking at it, though, is that it's driven by -- not by, necessarily, unique phone architecture related to specific OEMs, it's really by the fact that 4G, whether that be in U.S., Europe, China, increases dramatically the use of FBAR filters, which we are very, very well-positioned. It also implies, with 4G, an increased number of bands required on every -- almost every smartphone around, whether they be in China, Europe or the U.S. An increased content gives challenges to power, gives challenges to coexistence of different bands running on the same phone, and gives challenges to space, which leads to architectures that favor our designs and therefore leads to increased content in our handset business. That's not necessarily an issue of diversity, as much as a technological trend, architectural trend that has favored our businesses. In terms of capacity, we continue to invest, and whether we invest in CapEx or, as Tony articulated, whether we invest by building products, wafers, early to handle shop expected ramps, as evidenced in our inventory level this closing quarter, Q2, it is intended to be able to ensure our capability and our capacity in addressing fairly substantial demand and ramp up by several of our large OEM customers.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of Belon Curtin (sic) [Blayne Curtis] from Barclays.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: It's Blayne Curtis. Maybe you could talk about the CapEx that you mentioned, it was mostly FBAR in increase. What was the catalyst behind that? And then, Tony, what are you looking at for the full fiscal year?

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Well, again, we didn't give a full fiscal year on CapEx, we're doing it quarter-by-quarter. And the FBAR portion of it is probably a good third of what we were talking about in this $125 million. And just a reminder, the FBAR capacity pays for itself well within a year. So these are things we have line of sight that we've won, that we're excited about and we need the capacity desperately, because just -- we can't build anymore ahead than we've been building ahead right now. So for the full year, again, we're not giving a full forecast yet, and then we'll talk about it quarter-by-quarter until we get some stability, both in digesting LSI and in our outlook in FBAR.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Great. And then as a follow-up, you saw a nice mix to FBAR driving your gross margin higher, that continues in the guide. How do you look at this level of gross margin, and is this mix of FBAR sustainable when you look out at the ramps you have? The CapEx would suggest that, but just curious.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: As I mentioned earlier, on a trended basis of our wireless business, the mix of FBAR, in terms of discrete FBAR, particularly, in our business, particularly driven with China, but also more than China, is that it has, as is evident in our financials, been driving our overall gross margin to a level that we have never seen before. And a big part of it is on our wireless business. As Tony indicated, gross margin from our wireless business product line is pretty much running close to our corporate averages at this point.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q2 2014 Earnings Call, May 29, 2014
componenttext: Thank you, operator. Thank you for participating in today's earnings call. We look forward to talking with you again when we report our Third Quarter fiscal year 2014 financial results in August 2014.

headline: Avago Technologies Limited, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Aug 28, 2014
componenttext:
